comments:
I simply cannot get Eclipse to run on my AMD64 box, no matter what I try.  I am running under JDK1.6.0, 64-bit version of course, and I have also tried the blackdown 1.4.2 64-bit edition.  Furthermore, I tried version 3.1.1 of Eclipse.  The error I get under most configurations is the following.  After a while, they seem to accumulate until a dialog box pops up informing me that Eclipse has completely run out of memory and must shut down.  In eclipse.ini, I added the flags -Xms512m and -Xmx1024m, and I have 2GB of physical RAM.  Any hints would be greatly appreciated, this has been blocking me for months.  Thanks!

is there anything in the .log file?

From the trace it looks like Eclipse came up and you opend the preferences dialog and then it died.  How long was Eclipse up?
Clearing target milestone - this field should only be set by the committer to describe what milestone will contain the fix.

CC'ing Billy for x86_64 assistence.  Billy have you seen this type of error before?

You're using the 64-bit version of Eclipse too, right? :)

What kernel?  Any strange options?  What Linux distribution?

(In reply to comment #6)
> You're using the 64-bit version of Eclipse too, right? :)
> 
> What kernel?  Any strange options?  What Linux distribution?
> 

That's a good question, but yes, I am using the 64-bit version. :-)

 - Linux version 2.6.14.5 (root@localhost) (gcc version 4.0.1 (Gentoo 4.0.1, pie-8.7.8)) #1 Fri Jan 6 03:29:21 CST 2006

 - Gentoo 2005.1

 - jdk-6-rc-bin-b67-linux-i586-12_jan_2006

 - I am using native POSIX threads in GLIBC, and do not have support for non-native threads installed.

 - I use prelink.

I wish I could test it on another installation, but I don't have any other 64-bit boxes and don't want to go through that much work.  However, I may have to try that if you've never heard of this before.  I love beta software, but this problem very well may be a result of my early adoption strategy.  Another interesting fact I might add here is that a few months ago I still had this problem, but I could get a lot further.  After I compiled my C++ (CDT) project maybe 10-15 times, it would crash.  Now, I can't seem to do anything.  Thanks!

The Linux loader gives that error if you try and load a 64-bit library
from a 32-bit program, or vice-versa.  You likely mistakenly downloaded
the 32-bit version of the 1.5 JRE.

(In reply to comment #10)
> The Linux loader gives that error if you try and load a 64-bit library
> from a 32-bit program, or vice-versa.  You likely mistakenly downloaded
> the 32-bit version of the 1.5 JRE.
> 

I'm sorry, I was running the 32-bit version of Eclipse for that test.  I had both installed, but I used the correct version in my previous posts.  Anyway, I tried the 64-bit version of Eclipse (3.1.1) with the 64-bit version of 1.5.0, and it has the same problems.
